[[Robert Sturges]] <!-- Insignia --> |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= |identification_symbol_3= |identification_symbol_3_label= |identification_symbol_4= |identification_symbol_4_label= }} The '''Royal Marines Division''' was formed in August 1940 as the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Royal Marines]] expanded to meet operational demands during the [[World War II|Second World War]].
The RM Division's primary role was to serve as an [[amphibious warfare]] formation. It was to be organised on the same lines as an [[British Army|Army]] division with 3 [[infantry]] brigades, an [[artillery]] brigade, an [[Combat engineer|engineer]] battalion, a [[heavy machine gun|machine gun]] battalion, and a 'mobile' battalion equipped with motorcycles.<ref>''The Royal Marines 1939-93'' Nick van der Bijl (Osprey)</ref><ref>''Tell It to the Marines'' [[Michael Bennighof|Mike Bennighof]] (Avalanche Press)</ref>
== Operational history == [[File:Men of the Royal Marines Division training in snow during 1942.jpg|thumb|Men of the Royal Marines Division training in deep snow at [[Hawick]], Scotland during March 1942]] 101 Brigade, supported by 2 battalions from 102 Brigade, went into action at [[Dakar]], [[Senegal]] in July 1940 at part of [[Battle of Dakar|Operation Menace]], the unsuccessful attempt by the British and [[Free French]] to seize control of the [[Vichy French]] port in [[West Africa]]. 103 Brigade never reached full strength as its recruits were constantly drafted to provide personnel for the Royal Marines naval base defence forces. The division headquarters participated in the Allied planning for [[Battle of Madagascar|Operation Ironclad]] (the capture of [[Madagascar]]), but the RM division itself was not assigned to the operation as its infantry brigades were understrength and its divisional artillery had not formed. In 1943, the decision was taken to disband the division and reassign its personnel. Several of the infantry battalions were converted to [[British Commandos|Royal Marine Commandos]] and other divisional personnel were assigned as landing craft crews. The division headquarters under [[Robert Sturges|Major General Robert Sturges]] formed the new [[British Commandos|Headquarters Special Service Group (Commando)]].<ref>''The Royal Marines 1939-93'' Nick van der Bijl (Osprey)</ref><ref>''British Commandos 1940-46'' Tim Moreman (Osprey)</ref><ref>''Tell It to the Marines'' Mike Bennighof (Avalanche Press)</ref>
